case_name: Commissioner of Incometax v. Nainital Bank Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 601 and 602 of 1965 were filed from the judgment and decree dated April 12, 1962 of the Allahabad High Court in I.T.R. No. 484 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 601 602 of 1965. Appeals from the judgment and decree dated April 12, 1962 of the Allahabad High Court in I.T.R. No. 484 of 1960.

facts.text: The Nainital Bank Ltd. has its head office at Nainital and a branch at Ramnagar.

anchor.surface_text: The Nainital Bank Ltd., has its head office at Nainital and a branch at Ramnagar.

facts.text: Currency notes of the value of Rs. 1,06,000/- and a large quantity of jewellery pledged with the Bank by its constituents were stolen by dacoits on June 11, 1951 from the premises of the Bank.

anchor.surface_text: Currency numberes of the value of Rs. 1,06,000/- and a large quantity of jewellery pledged with the Bank by its companystituents were stolen by dacoits on June 11, 1951 from the premises of the Bank.

facts.text: The Bank claimed in its return for the assessment year 1952-53 the loss of currency notes as a permissible deduction.

anchor.surface_text: The Bank claimed in its return for the assessment year 1952-53 the loss of currency numberes as a permissible deduction.

facts.text: The departmental authorities disallowed the claim for currency loss deduction.

anchor.surface_text: The departmental authorities disallowed the claim.

facts.text: The claim for currency loss was allowed by the High Court of Allahabad and confirmed by this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Nainital Bank Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: But the claim was allowed by the High Court of Allahabad and that order was companyfirmed by this Court see Commissioner of Incometax v. Nainital Bank Ltd. 1 .

facts.text: In regard to the loss of jewellery the Bank settled the claims of the constituents who had pledged their jewellery.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the loss of jewellery the Bank settled the claims of the companystituents who had pledged their jewellery.

facts.text: The terms of settlement were: when market value of jewellery exceeded amount advanced, difference paid by Bank to constituent; when less, difference recovered from constituent.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of settlement were these when the market value of the jewellery pledged exceeded the amount advanced, the difference was paid by the Bank to the companystituent when the market value of the jewellery was less than the amount advanced, the difference was recovered from the companystituent.

facts.text: Under the adjustments, in the year 1952 the Bank made a total payment of Rs. 48,891/- .

anchor.surface_text: Under the adjustments made in this manner, in the year 1952 the Bank made a total payment of Rs. 48,89 1 -

facts.text: In the year 1953 the Bank paid Rs. 1,21,760.

anchor.surface_text: and in the year 1953 the Bank paid Rs. 1,21,760.

facts.text: In its returns for assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55 the Bank claimed the amounts paid to constituents in computing taxable income.

anchor.surface_text: In its returns for the assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55 the Bank claimed in companyputing its taxable income the amounts so paid to the companystituents.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer disallowed the claims.

anchor.surface_text: The income-tax Officer disallowed the claims and the order was companyfirmed in appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: The disallowance was confirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The income-tax Officer disallowed the claims and the order was companyfirmed in appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal was unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal was also unsuccessful.

facts.text: The Tribunal referred the question to the High Court of Allahabad.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal submitted a statement of the case and referred the following question to the High Court of Allahabad for opinion Whether on a true interpretation of s. 10  1 , s. 10  2   xi  and s. 10  2   xv  of the Indian Income-tax Act, the claims for the losses of Rs. 48,891/- and Rs. 1,21,760/were permissible in the assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55 respectively ?

facts.text: Before the High Court the claim for deduction under s. 10(2)(xi) was abandoned by the Bank.

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court the claim for deduction under s. 10  2   xi  was abandoned by the Bank,

facts.text: The High Court negatived the claim under s. 10(1).

anchor.surface_text: and the High Court negatived the claim of the Bank for deduction of the amount under s. 10  1 .

facts.text: The High Court held the amounts were deductible under s. 10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court held that having regard to the true nature of the settlements made with the companystituents the amounts credited as the value of jewellery against the claim of the companystituents for amounts advanced to them must be regarded as expenditure within the meaning of s. 10  2   xv  and since such credit was given by the Bank in the interest of its business, the amounts paid were liable to be deducted in companyputing the taxable income.

facts.text: The Commissioner of Income-tax appealed with certificate granted by the High Court under s. 66A(2) of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax has appealed with certificate granted by the High Court under s. 66 A  2  of the Income- tax Act.

facts.text: The Bank carries on banking business and advances loans on the security of jewellery.

anchor.surface_text: The Bank is carrying on banking business and advances loans on the security of jewellery.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.

anchor.surface_text: - The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.

concepts.unlisted_description: Standard of care for pledged property

anchor.surface_text: The Bank is carrying on banking business and advances loans on the security of jewellery. The credit of a banking business is very sensitive it largely thrives upon the confidence which its constituents have in its management. To maintain that confidence the management has often to make concessions and thereby to preserve the goodwill of the business and its relations with the clientele.

concepts.interpretation: Payments to maintain business confidence, goodwill and clientele relations, even if not strictly legally required, constitute expenditure for purpose of business.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 10(2)(xi) of the Indian Income-tax Act

issues.text: Whether on a true interpretation of s. 10(1), s. 10(2)(xi) and s. 10(2)(xv) of the Indian Income-tax Act, the claims for the losses of Rs. 48,891/- and Rs. 1,21,760/were permissible in the assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55 respectively?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on a true interpretation of s. 10  1 , s. 10  2   xi  and s. 10  2   xv  of the Indian Income-tax Act, the claims for the losses of Rs. 48,891/- and Rs. 1,21,760/were permissible in the assessment years 1953-54

issues.text: Whether by writing-off either partially or wholly the amounts due from its constituents in its books of account the Bank expended or laid out expenditure within the meaning of s. 10(2)(xv)

anchor.surface_text: In these appeals counsel for the Commissioner raised two contentions that by writing-off either partially or wholly the amounts due from its companystituents in its books of account the Bank did number expend or lay out expenditure within the meaning of s. 10  2   xv  -and that in any event the expenditure was number laid out wholly and exclusively for the purposes of the business of the Bank.

issues.text: Whether the expenditure was laid out wholly and exclusively for the purposes of the business of the Bank

anchor.surface_text: expenditure within the meaning of s. 10  2   xv  -and that in any event the expenditure was number laid out wholly and exclusively for the purposes of the business of the Bank. In its numbermal meaning the expression expenditure denotes spending ,or paying out or away i.e. something that goes out of the companyfers of the assessee.

issues.text: Whether the settlements made by the Bank with its constituents were mere forbearance to recover the amount or actual expenditure

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Commissioner submitted that when the Bank advanced a loan to its companystituent it incurred expenditure and when the Bank failed to recover under an arrangement with the companystituent the amount due to it, there was merely an act of forbearance to enforce the demand and such an act of forbearance was number expenditure within the meaning of s. 10  2   xv . Mere forbearance to realize a claim, it may be accepted, is number expenditure within the meaning of the Act

arguments.claim: By writing-off either partially or wholly the amounts due from its constituents in its books of account the Bank did not expend or lay out expenditure within the meaning of s. 10(2)(xv)

anchor.surface_text: In these appeals counsel for the Commissioner raised two contentions that by writing-off either partially or wholly the amounts due from its companystituents in its books of account the Bank did not expend or lay out expenditure within the meaning of s. 10  2   xv

court_response_anchor.surface_text: entions that by writing-off either partially or wholly the amounts due from its companystituents in its books of account the Bank did number expend or

arguments.court_reasoning: Expenditure does not necessarily involve actual delivery; settlement of cross claims by debiting the assessee's account constitutes expenditure

arguments.claim: In any event the expenditure was not laid out wholly and exclusively for the purposes of the business of the Bank

anchor.surface_text: -and that in any event the expenditure was not laid out wholly and exclusively for the purposes of the business of the Bank. In its normal meaning the expression expenditure denotes spending

court_response_anchor.surface_text: within the meaning of the Act but we are number called upon to companysider whether the advances made by the Bank to its companystituents may in cert

arguments.court_reasoning: Expenditure laid out to preserve goodwill, confidence and relations with clientele in sensitive banking business

arguments.claim: When the Bank failed to recover under an arrangement with the constituent the amount due to it, there was merely an act of forbearance to enforce the demand and such an act of forbearance was not expenditure within the meaning of s. 10(2)(xv)

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Commissioner submitted that when the Bank advanced a loan to its companystituent it incurred expenditure and when the Bank failed to recover under an arrangement with the companystituent the amount due to it, there was merely an act of forbearance to enforce the demand and such an act of forbearance was number expenditure within the meaning of s. 10  2   xv .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the balance due only is paid, the amount which is debited against the assessee in the settlement of accounts may ,appropriately be termed expenditure

arguments.court_reasoning: Mere forbearance is not expenditure but here settlements were bilateral with admission of mutual liabilities and payment of difference

arguments.claim: The Bank was under no legal liability to pay to the constituents the value of the jewellery pledged with it as a pledgee bailee having discharged duty of care by providing adequate watchmen

anchor.surface_text: It was urged by the Commissioner that the Bank was under numberlegal liability to pay to the companystituents the value of the jewellery pledged with it. It was said that the Bank was, as a pledge, a bailee of the jewellery and was in law required to take as much care of the pledged jewellery as a person of ordinary prudence would take under similar circumstances of his own jewellery of the same bulk quantity and value, and the Bank having provided an adequate number of watchmen,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s. 10  2   xv . Mere forbearance to realize a claim, it may be accepted, is number expenditure within the meaning of the Act but we are number called

arguments.court_reasoning: Granting no strict legal liability, the issue is whether admitting liability and paying served the purpose of business via commercial expediency

arguments.claim: Having regard to the true nature of the settlements made with the constituents the amounts credited as the value of jewellery against the claim of the constituents for amounts advanced to them must be regarded as expenditure within the meaning of s. 10(2)(xv) and since such credit was given by the Bank in the interest of its business, the amounts paid were liable to be deducted

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court held that having regard to the true nature of the settlements made with the companystituents the amounts credited as the value of jewellery against the claim of the companystituents for amounts advanced to them must be regarded as expenditure within the meaning of s. 10  2   xv  and since such credit was given by the Bank in the interest of its business, the amounts paid were liable to be deducted in companyputing the taxable income.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: can it be said that there was by the settlements mere forbearance to recover the amount. The settlements made by the Bank with its companystituents we

arguments.court_reasoning: Confirms settlements as bilateral expenditure for business purposes under commercial expediency to maintain goodwill

arguments.claim: The settlement consisted of two constituent elements - paying by the Bank of the value of the jewellery pledged with it against receipt from the constituent of the amount which was recoverable by the Bank. The first element of the transaction would appropriately be deemed expenditure laid out wholly and exclusively for business under s. 10(2)(xv)

anchor.surface_text: The settlement companysisted of two companystituent elements-paying by the Bank of the value of the jewellery pledged with it against receipt from the companystituent of the amount which was recoverable by the Bank. The first element of the transaction would appropriately be deemed expenditure and such expenditure having been laid out for protecting and furthering the business of the Bank was properly admissible under s. 10  2   xv  of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

arguments.claim: Paying to the constituents the price of the jewellery stolen in a robbery or a burglary was therefore expenditure for the purpose of the business wholly and exclusively in the interest of the business

anchor.surface_text: In choosing the second alternative, in our judgment, the Bank laid out expenditure for the purpose of its business. Paying to the. companystituents the price of the jewellery stolen in a robbery or a burglary was therefore expenditure for the purpose of the business. There can be numberdoubt that the expenditure was wholly and exclusively in the interest of the business.

holdings.text: expenditure does not necessarily involve actual delivery or parting with money or property. If there are cross claims-one by the assessee against a stranger and the other by the stranger against the assessee and as a result of accounting the balance due only is paid, the amount which is debited against the assessee in the settlement of accounts may, appropriately be termed expenditure within the meaning of s. 10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: But expenditure does not necessarily involve actual delivery or parting with money or property. If there are cross claims-one by the assessee against a stranger and the other by the stranger against the assessee and as a result of accounting the balance due only is paid,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Expenditure in normal meaning includes settlement of cross claims by accounting debit, without physical parting of cash or property.

holdings.text: Mere forbearance to realize a claim is not expenditure but the settlements were bilateral admissions of mutual liabilities resulting in payment of difference, constituting laid out expenditure equal to value of jewellery.

anchor.surface_text: Mere forbearance to realize a claim, it may be accepted, is not expenditure within the meaning of the Act but we are not called upon to consider whether the advances made by the Bank to its constituents may in certain circumstances constitute expenditure. Nor can it be said that there was by the settlements mere forbearance to recover the amount.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes mere unilateral forbearance from bilateral settlements where bank admits liability for jewellery value against constituent's loan repayment.

holdings.text: Even granting no strict legal liability as pledgee-bailee due to discharge of duty of care, admitting liability and paying constitutes expenditure for purpose of business under commercial expediency.

anchor.surface_text: Granting that on proof that it had taken as much care of the jewellery pledged with it as it would have taken, if it belonged to it, the Bank could enforce its rights and recover the full amount due from the constituents, the question still remains whether in admitting liability for the value of the jewellery pledged, the Bank laid out expenditure for the purpose of the business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal liability not required; focus on whether payment serves business interest beyond strict rights.

holdings.text: The expenditure was laid out wholly and exclusively for the purpose of business as it preserved confidence, goodwill and clientele relations in sensitive banking business.

anchor.surface_text: The question is not about the strict enforcement of the legal rights and obligations between the Bank and its constituents. The sole question is whether the Bank in incurring the expenditure acted in the interest of and for the purpose of its business. The Bank is carrying on banking business and advances loans on the security of jewellery. The credit of a banking business is very sensitive it largely thrives upon the confidence which its constituents have in its management.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Banking goodwill sensitive; concessions to maintain confidence and relations qualify as business purpose expenditure.

holdings.text: The settlements consisted of paying value of pledged jewellery against receipt of loan amount; first element deemed expenditure laid out wholly and exclusively for business, admissible under s. 10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: We hold accordingly that the settlements with the constituents and the consequent posting of entries in the books of account cannot be regarded as forbearance to enforce the claim of the Bank to recover the loans advanced. The settlement consisted of two constituent elements-paying by the Bank of the value of the jewellery pledged with it against receipt from the constituent of the amount which was recoverable by the Bank.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Breaks settlement into elements; payment of jewellery value is deductible business expenditure, answering referred question affirmatively.
